Comment: Well... not neceessarily.  If there's already a vaccine that's known to be safe and effective, it makes more sense to test against that than a placebo for a few reasons:  1. There's a huge ethical problem.  A bunch of people will get a saline injection rather than a vaccination and nobody will ever know who was who. 2. This translates into a difficulty in finding test subjects.  "We're looking for people to put their children forward for this new measles vaccine as part of their immunisation programme.  If your child is put into this, there's a chance they will get no measles vaccine at all and you won't know!". 3. The question you want answered often isn't "is this better than a placebo?".  It's "is this better than the best product currently on the market?".  And if the answer to that is "no it's not" - who cares if it's better than a placebo?  Getting something set up for mass production isn't cheap; there's not an awful lot of point in going to that expense for something that's substantially less effective than the current state of the art.
